channel.title: Time Series on 3K: Dynamics and Heterogeneity
channel.description: Recent content in Time Series on 3K: Dynamics and Heterogeneity

item.title: The Falklands
item.description: The data for the Falklands problem are shown below. library(haven) br7983 <- read_dta("br7983.dta") A brief glimpse. head(br7983) ## empx empxl empxld govpop month pexnew pexnewl retailpj thatsat ## 1 4.2 1.435085 NA 36.0 7907 -3 2.995732 15.8 41 ## 2 4.2 1.435085 0 36.0 7908 -4 2.944439 15.8 45 ## 3 4.2 1.435085 0 36.0 7909 0 3.135494 16.5 45 ## 4 4.2 1.435085 0 35.5 7910 0 3.135494 17.

item.title: Forecasts and Highcharts
item.description: Beautiful forecasting can be quick and easy I will grab the adjusted closing price of Ford stock (F) from January 1, 2018. Use the forecast package to find an ARIMA model and forecast it for 50 periods. Use highcharter to plot it inside a framewidget that is appropriate with the markdown. library(tidyquant) library(forecast) library(highcharter) library(widgetframe) A.Stock <- "F" %>% tq_get(., from = "2018-01-01") A.

item.title: Forecasts and Highcharts
item.description: Beautiful forecasting can be quick and easy I will grab the adjusted closing price of Ford stock (F) from January 1, 2018. Use the forecast package to find an ARIMA model and forecast it for 50 periods. Use highcharter to plot it inside a framewidget that is appropriate with the markdown. library(tidyquant) ## Loading required package: lubridate ## ## Attaching package: 'lubridate' ## The following object is masked from 'package:base': ## ## date ## Loading required package: PerformanceAnalytics ## Loading required package: xts ## Loading required package: zoo ## ## Attaching package: 'zoo' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ## ## as.

item.title: ACF and PACF on Generated Data
item.description: Simulating Data Simulating data under an ARIMA model in R is made rather easy. From the documentation on arima in stats, we obtain that $$ X_t = a1 X{t-1} + a{2} X{t-2} + \ldots + a{p} X{t-p} + b1 \epsilon{t-1} + b[2] \epsilon{t-2} + \ldots + b{q} \epsilon{t-q} $$ by construction. This can be adjusted with the rand.gen argument. library(ggplot2) library(forecast) my.data <- arima.sim(list(ar=c(0.7,0.2)), n=100) my.data2 <- data.frame(x=seq(1,100), y=my.data) ggplot(my.
